# Base R Plotting

The **classic framework** of plotting.

Contains separate **function for each 'type'** of plot.

<br>

```{r, eval = FALSE}
# Histogram in base R
hist(x = baselers$age,
     xlab = "Age",
     ylab = "Frequency",
     main = "Baselers Age")
```

]

.pull-right5[

```{r, echo = F}
# Histogram in base R
hist(x = baselers$age,
     xlab = "Age",
     ylab = "Frequency",
     main = "Baselers Age")
```

]

# Problems with Base R plotting

.pull-left35[

- Default plots look pretty <b>outdated</b>.<br>

- Plots can quickly require a <b>LOT of code</b>.<br>

- Can't store plots as <b>objects</b> to reference and update later</font><br>

### Solution: ggplot2

```{r, echo = FALSE, out.width = "45%"}
knitr::include_graphics("https://www.r-graph-gallery.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/09/ggplot_hex.jpg")
```



]

.pull-right55[

This plot would take <b>a lot of code in Base R</b> but **just 10 lines of code**, 5 of which controlling the labels, in `ggplot2`.

```{r, echo = FALSE, fig.width=7, fig.height = 4}
# Add a regression line for all classes
ggplot(data = mpg, mapping = aes(x = displ, y = hwy, color = class)) +
  geom_point(size = 3, alpha = .9) + 
  geom_smooth(col = "blue", method = "lm")+
  labs(x = "Engine Displacement in Liters",
       y = "Highway miles per gallon",
       title = "MPG data",
       subtitle = "Cars with higher engine displacement tend to have lower highway mpg",
       caption = "Source: mpg data in ggplot2") + theme_bw()

```


]

---

## Grammar of Graphics in ggplot2

.pull-left45[

The Grammar of graphics breaks down plots into several key pieces:

| Aesthetics| Description|
|:------|:----|
| Data| What dataframe contains the data?|
| axes| What does the x-axis, y-axis, color (etc) represent?|
| color| What does color represent? |
| size | What does size represent? |
| geometries| What kind of geometric object do you want to plot?|
| facets| Should there be groups of plots?|

]


.pull-right45[

```{r, echo = FALSE, fig.width=7}
# Add a regression line for all classes
ggplot(data = mpg, mapping = aes(x = displ, y = hwy, color = class)) +
  geom_point(size = 3, alpha = .9) + 
  geom_smooth(col = "blue", method = "lm")+
  labs(x = "Engine Displacement in Liters",
       y = "Highway miles per gallon",
       title = "MPG data",
       subtitle = "Cars with higher engine displacement tend to have lower highway mpg",
       caption = "Source: mpg data in ggplot2") + theme_bw()

```

]


---

## Our goal: Creating this plot

.pull-left45[

**Data**

- Use the `mpg` tibble

**Aesthetics**

- Show engine displacement (`disp`) on the x axis
- Show highway miles per gallon (`hwy`) on the y-axis
- Color plotting elements by the class of car (`class`)

**Geometric objects**

- Show data as points
- Add a regression line

**Labels and themes**

- Add plotting labels
- Use a black and white plotting theme

]


.pull-right5[

```{r, echo = FALSE, fig.width = 7, fig.height = 5}
# Add a regression line for all classes

ggplot(data = mpg, 
       mapping = aes(x = displ, y = hwy, color = class)) +
  geom_point(size = 3, alpha = .9) + 
  geom_smooth(col = "blue", method = "lm")+
  labs(x = "Engine Displacement in Liters",
       y = "Highway miles per gallon",
       title = "MPG data",
       subtitle = "Cars with higher engine displacement tend to have lower highway mpg",
       caption = "Source: mpg data in ggplot2") + theme_bw()

```


]

# `ggplot(data)`


.pull-left45[

To create a ggplot2 object, use the `ggplot()` function

`ggplot()` has two main arguments:

- `data` - A data frame (aka tibble)
- `mapping` - A call to `aes()`

]


.pull-right45[

```{r, fig.width=4, fig.height=4}
ggplot(data = mpg)
```

]


---

# `ggplot(mapping = aes())`


.pull-left4[

An **aesthetic mapping** is a visual property of the objects in your plot. 

Use `aes()` to assign columns in your dataframe to properties in your plot.

Common aesthetics are...

| aesthetics| Description|
|:------|:----|
|     `x`, `y`|    Data mapped to coordinates|
|     `color`, `fill`|    Border and fill colors|
|     `alpha`| Transparency|
|    `size`|  Size|
|    `shape`|  Shape|

]

.pull-right5[

```{r, out.width = "70%", fig.width = 4, fig.height = 4}
ggplot(data = mpg,
       mapping = aes(x = displ, y = hwy))
```

]

---

# Adding elements to plots with '+'

.pull-left45[

Once you have specified data with `data` argument, and global aesthetics with `mapping = aes()`, add additional elements to the plot with `+`

The `+` sign works just like the pipe `%>%` in dplyr. It just means "and then..."

```{r, eval = FALSE, fig.width = 5, fig.height = 4, out.width = "90%"}
ggplot(data = mpg,
       mapping = aes(x = displ,
                     y = hwy)) + #and then
       geom_point() 
```

]


.pull-right5[


```{r, echo = FALSE, fig.width = 5, fig.height = 4, out.width = "90%"}
ggplot(data = mpg,
       mapping = aes(x = displ, y = hwy)) + 
  geom_point()
```


]


---

# Geometric objects (geoms)


.pull-left4[

A **geom** is a geometric object in a plot that represents data

To add a geom to a plot, just include ` + geom_X()` where X is the type of geom.

Common geoms are...

| geom| output|
|:------|:----|
|     `geom_point()`|    Points|
|     `geom_bar()`|    Bar|
|     `geom_boxplot()`| Boxplot
|     `geom_count()`| Points with size reflecting frequency|
|     `geom_smooth()`|  Smoothed line|

]

.pull-right5[

```{r, echo = FALSE, fig.width = 5, fig.height = 4, out.width = "90%"}
ggplot(data = mpg,
       mapping = aes(x = displ, y = hwy)) + 
  geom_point()
```


]

# Overriding aesthetics

.pull-left45[

If you add additional plotting aesthetics, they will <b>override</b> the general plotting aesthetics.

This is what happens, when you don't override...

<br>

```{r, fig.width = 7, fig.height = 4, eval = F}
ggplot(data = mpg, 
       mapping = aes(x = displ, y = hwy,
                     col = class)) +
  geom_point() + 
  geom_smooth() # no overriding
```

]

.pull-right45[


```{r, fig.width = 6, echo = FALSE}
ggplot(data = mpg, 
       mapping = aes(x = displ, y = hwy, col = class)) +
  geom_point() + 
  geom_smooth()
```

# Add labels with `labs()`

.pull-left45[

You can add labels to a plot with the `labs()` function

`labs()` arguments are ...

- `title` - Main title
- `subtitle` - Subtitle
- `caption` - Caption below


```{r, echo = TRUE, eval = FALSE}
ggplot(...) +
  labs(x = "Engine Displ...",
       y = "Highway miles...",
       title = "MPG data",
       subtitle = "Cars with ...",
       caption = "Source...")
```

# Themes with `theme_XX()`

.pull-left45[

Common themes are...

`theme_bw()`<br>
`theme_minimal()`<br>
`theme_classic()`<br>
`theme_light()`<br>
`theme_dark()`

```{r, fig.width = 8, echo = FALSE}
  geom_point() +
```

# Assigning a ggplot to an object


.pull-left4[

1) ggplot returns an object of the class "gg".<br>
2) You can assign the result of `ggplot` to an object.<br>
3) Evaluating the object will show the plot.<br>
4) You can even edit existing `ggplot` objects.<br>

```{r, fig.width = 8}
# Create myplot
myplot <- ggplot(data = mpg,
                 aes(x = displ,
                     y = hwy)) + 
              geom_point() + 
              theme_bw()
class(myplot)
```

]

.pull-right5[

```{r, fig.width = 6, fig.height = 4}
myplot # Evaluate myplot
```

]

# `ggsave()`

.pull-left5[

To save plots to a file (e.g.; .jpg, .pdf, .png), use the `ggsave()` function.

`ggsave()` main arguments are...

|Argument| Definition|
|:-------|:----------|
|`filename`|File name|
|`plot`|Plotting object|
|`device`|File type (e.g.; "pdf", "jpeg", "png")|
|`path`|File path to save plot|
|`width`|Plot width (inches)|
|`height`|Plot height (inches)|

]


.pull-right45[

Save ggplot object called myplot to a pdf file...<br>
```{r, eval = FALSE}
# Create myplot object
myplot <- ggplot(...)

# Create "myplot.pdf", from myplot
ggsave(filename = "myplot.pdf",
       plot = myplot,
       device = "pdf",
       path = "figures",
       width = 6, 
       height = 4)
```
